"}, {"content": "The Hindu one.

Explanation:

In Hinduism, the caste system is a significant aspect of life. It is believed that each caste has its own set of duties and responsibilities. The caste system is rigidly structured, and it is difficult to move from one caste to another. This rigid structure is also reflected in the religious practices of Hindus.

Hindus are divided into different castes, which are further divided into sub-castes. Each caste has its own set of religious practices, including prayers, rituals, and customs. The caste system is deeply ingrained in the Indian culture, and it is difficult to break free from it.

In contrast, Buddhism is a religion that originated in India and was founded by Siddhartha Gautama. The religion is based on the teachings of the Buddha, who is believed to have attained enlightenment. Buddhism is a non-theistic religion, and it does not have a rigid caste system.

The caste system is deeply ingrained in Hinduism, and it is difficult to break free from it. In contrast, Buddhism is a religion that originated in India and was founded by Siddhartha Gautama.
